titleStmt.title: Occasion'd by the Bishop's Endeavours to obtain an Act of Parliament

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Written by an honest Curate.
in margin faintly writtenOld·Ola Latimer preaching did fairly describe
A Bishop, who rubd all the rest of the Tribe;
And who is this Bishop? and where does he dwell?
Why truly 'tis Satan, Arch Bishop of Hell;
And he was a Primate, & he wore a Mitre,
Surrounded with Iewels of Sulphur & Nitre.
How nearly this Bishop our Bishops resembles;
But his has the odds, who believes, and who trembles.
Cou'd You see his grim Face, for a Pound to a Penny,
You'd swear it must be the Baboon of Kilkenny.
Poor Satan will think the Comparison odious,
I wish I cou'd fine him out one more Commodious.
But this, I am sure, the most Revrd. old Dragon
Has got on the Bench many Bishops Suffragan
And most men believe, he presides there Incog:
To give them by turns an invisible Iog.
Our Prelates puft up with wealth and with Pride,
To Hell on the Backs of the Clergy wouldwou'd ride,
They mounted, and labour'd with whip and with Spur;
In vain: For the Devil a parson wou'd stir.
So the Commons unhors'd them; & this was their Doom,
On their Crosiers to ride like a witch on a bro
Tho' they Gallop so fast, on the road You may find 'em,
They have left us but three out of twenty behind 'em:
Lord Bolter's good Grace, Lord Carr, and Lord Howard,
In spitspight of the Devil wou'd still be untoward;
They came of good Blood, & could not endure
Their former Companions shou'd beg at their DoorWhen Christ was betrayd unto Pilate the Praetor;
In a dozen Apostles but one prov'd a Traytor;
One Traytor alone, & faithfull eleven,
But we can afford You Six Traytors in Seven.
What a Clutter with Chippings, Dividings & Cleavings
And the Clergy, forsooth, must take up with their Leavings──
If making Divisions was all their Intent,
We thank'em, they've done it, but not as they meant;
And so may Such Bishops for ever divide,
That no honest Heathens wou'd be on their side
Now hear an Allusion: a Mitre You know
Is divided above, but united below;
Shou'd the Bottom be split, our Prelates wou'd dread;
That the Mitre wou'd never stick fast on their Head;
And Yet they have learnt the chief art of a Sovereign,
As Matchiavel taught'em, Divide, and ye govern.
But courage, my Lords, tho' it cannot be said,
That one cloven tongue ever sat on Your Head,
I'll hold You a groat & I wish I cou'd see it,
If Your Stockings were off, You cou'd show cloven feet
But, hold, cry the Bishops, and give us fair Play,
Before You condemn Us, hear what we can say;
What truer affection cou'd ever be shown,
Than saving Your souls by damning our own;
And what have we not practic'd all methods to gain You,
With the Tyth of the Tyth of the Tythe to maintain You;
Provided a Fund for building You Spittles,
You're only to live four Years without Victuals?
Content my Good Lords, but let us change blot·Hands;
First, take You our Tyths, & give us Your Lands.
So God bless the blot·King, and three of Our Mitres;
And God bless the Commons, for biting the Biters.803-300L
